### Create New TanStack Start Application

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/tanstack-start

Initializes a new TanStack Start project using the official `create-start-app` command. This sets up the basic project structure before adding Convex specific configurations and dependencies.

```bash
npx create-start-app@latest
```

--------------------------------

### Install Convex Client and Dotenv for Node.js

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/nodejs

Installs the `convex` package, which provides a client for interacting with the Convex backend, and `dotenv` for loading environment variables from `.env` files.

```bash
npm install convex dotenv
```

--------------------------------

### Install Convex and React Query Client Libraries

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/tanstack-start

Installs the necessary npm packages for integrating Convex with TanStack Start. This includes the main `convex` client library, `@convex-dev/react-query` for React Query integration, and core TanStack React Router and React Query packages.

```bash
npm install convex @convex-dev/react-query @tanstack/react-router-with-query @tanstack/react-query
```

--------------------------------

### Install Convex Client and Svelte Library

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/svelte

After navigating into the newly created SvelteKit project directory, this command installs the necessary Convex packages. It includes the core `convex` client and the `convex-svelte` integration library.

```bash
cd my-app && npm install convex convex-svelte
```

--------------------------------

### Initialize Convex with TanStack Start Template

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/tanstack-start

Use this command to quickly set up a new TanStack Start project integrated with Convex. This command leverages the Convex CLI to scaffold a pre-configured project, providing a rapid starting point for development.

```bash
npm create convex@latest -- -t tanstack-start
```

--------------------------------

### Install Convex npm package and Python client/dotenv

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/python

This sequence of commands navigates into the 'my-app' directory, initializes a new npm project, installs the 'convex' npm package for backend development, and then installs the 'convex' Python client library and 'python-dotenv' within the virtual environment.

```bash
cd my-app && npm init -y && npm install convex && venv/bin/pip install convex python-dotenv
```

--------------------------------

### Initialize Node.js Project and Install Convex

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/android

NPM commands to initialize a new Node.js project and install the Convex client library needed for backend development and deployment management.

```bash
npm init -y
npm install convex
```

--------------------------------

### Install Convex Dependencies

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/vue

Install the Convex client library and Vue integration package into the project. These packages enable communication with Convex backend and provide Vue composables for data querying.

```bash
cd my-vue-app && npm install convex convex-vue
```

--------------------------------

### Install Convex and convex-nuxt module

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/nuxt

Install the Convex library and the convex-nuxt module to enable Convex integration in the Nuxt application. This adds the necessary dependencies and Nuxt module configuration.

```bash
cd my-nuxt-app && npm install convex && npx nuxi module add convex-nuxt
```

```bash
git clone https://github.com/get-convex/convex-tutorial.git
cd convex-tutorial
npm install
```

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/script-tag

Initializes a new npm project within a created directory, setting up the basic project structure for a Convex application. This command ensures the project is ready for package installation and development.

```bash
mkdir my-project && cd my-project && npm init -y
```

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/client/nextjs/pages-router/quickstart

Install the convex npm package which provides React hooks and client utilities for querying Convex backend functions from your Next.js application.

```bash
cd my-app && npm install convex
```

Initialize a new npm project and install the Convex client and server library in your Swift project directory. This sets up the necessary backend dependencies for Convex integration.

```bash
npm init -y
npm install convex
```

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/client/nextjs/pages-router/quickstart

Run the Next.js development server which starts the application on localhost:3000. The app will display the list of tasks fetched from your Convex backend.

```bash
npm run dev
```

```bash

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/agents/files

npm run setup
npm run dev

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/vue

Launch the Vue development server which will be available at localhost:5173 for testing the application with live reload capabilities.

```bash
npm run dev
```

--------------------------------

### Fetch and subscribe to Convex data using Python client

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/python

This Python script initializes a `ConvexClient`, loading the Convex deployment URL from environment variables. It demonstrates how to perform a one-time query to the `tasks:get` Convex API and also how to subscribe to real-time updates, printing the fetched data in a loop.

```python
import os

from convex import ConvexClient
from dotenv import load_dotenv

load_dotenv(".env.local")
CONVEX_URL = os.getenv("CONVEX_URL")
# or you can hardcode your deployment URL instead
# CONVEX_URL = "https://happy-otter-123.convex.cloud"

client = ConvexClient(CONVEX_URL)

print(client.query("tasks:get"))

for tasks in client.subscribe("tasks:get"):
    print(tasks)
    # this loop lasts forever, ctrl-c to exit it
```

--------------------------------

### Install Convex Library in Remix Project

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/remix

Navigates into the newly created Remix application directory and installs the 'convex' npm package. This package provides the necessary client and server-side utilities to interact with Convex.

```bash
cd my-remix-app && npm install convex
```

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/remix

Initializes a new Remix project named 'my-remix-app' using the official Remix CLI. This command sets up the basic project structure and dependencies required to start a Remix application.

```bash
npx create-remix@latest my-remix-app
```

### Run the Rust application

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/rust

Executes the compiled Rust application. This command starts the `main` function, which will connect to your Convex deployment, fetch the task data, and display it in the terminal.

```bash
cargo run
```

### Execute Python script from virtual environment

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/python

This command executes the 'main.py' script using the Python interpreter from the virtual environment. This ensures that the script runs with the project-specific dependencies installed.

```bash
venv/bin/python -m main
```

--------------------------------

### Configure TanStack Router with Convex Client and Provider

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/tanstack-start

Replaces the `app/router.tsx` file to set up `ConvexClient` and `ConvexQueryClient`. It then wires in a `ConvexProvider` to make Convex available to all components within the TanStack Start application, enabling seamless database interactions.

```typescript
import { createRouter } from "@tanstack/react-router";
import { QueryClient } from "@tanstack/react-query";
import { routerWithQueryClient } from "@tanstack/react-router-with-query";
import { ConvexQueryClient } from "@convex-dev/react-query";
import { ConvexProvider } from "convex/react";
import { routeTree } from "./routeTree.gen";

export function getRouter() {
  const CONVEX_URL = (import.meta as any).env.VITE_CONVEX_URL!;
  if (!CONVEX_URL) {
    console.error("missing envar VITE_CONVEX_URL");
  }
  const convexQueryClient = new ConvexQueryClient(CONVEX_URL);

  const queryClient: QueryClient = new QueryClient({
    defaultOptions: {
      queries: {
        queryKeyHashFn: convexQueryClient.hashFn(),
        queryFn: convexQueryClient.queryFn(),
      },
    },
  });
  convexQueryClient.connect(queryClient);

  const router = routerWithQueryClient(
    createRouter({
      routeTree,
      defaultPreload: "intent",
      context: { queryClient },
      scrollRestoration: true,
      Wrap: ({ children }) => (
        <ConvexProvider client={convexQueryClient.convexClient}>
          {children}
        </ConvexProvider>
      ),
    }),
    queryClient,
  );

  return router;
}

```

--------------------------------

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/react-native

This command initiates the Expo development server for the React Native application. It compiles the project, opens a development console, and provides a QR code to run the app on a physical device or emulator.

```bash
npm start
```

```bash
npm install @convex-dev/agent

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/react-native

```bash
cd my-app && npm install convex
```

--------------------------------

### GET /

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/functions/http-actions

A basic example of an HTTP action route that responds with a simple greeting message including the request URL. This demonstrates the fundamental structure of an HTTP GET endpoint.

```APIDOC
## GET /

### Description
This endpoint serves as a basic example, returning a greeting message that includes the URL from which the request originated.

### Method
GET

### Endpoint
/

### Parameters
#### Path Parameters
- No path parameters.

#### Query Parameters
- No query parameters.

#### Request Body
- No request body.

### Request Example
N/A

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
- **message** (string) - A greeting message including the request URL.

#### Response Example
```json
"Hello from https://<your-deployment-name>.convex.site/"
```
```

--------------------------------

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/nodejs

Initializes a new Node.js project within a created directory, accepting default settings and configuring the project to use ES modules.

```bash
mkdir my-project && cd my-project && npm init -y && npm pkg set type="module"
```

--------------------------------

### Install Convex client and server libraries

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/rust

Installs the `convex` npm package for backend development and adds the `convex` Rust client library, the `tokio` asynchronous runtime, and `dotenvy` for environment variable management to the Rust project's dependencies. This prepares both the JavaScript backend and Rust frontend environments.

```bash
npm init -y && npm install convex && cargo add convex tokio dotenvy
```

### Create React App with Vite and TypeScript

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/react

This command initializes a new React project using Vite with a TypeScript template. It sets up the basic project structure and dependencies for a modern React application.

```bash
npm create vite@latest my-app -- --template react-ts
```

--------------------------------

### Configure TanStack Router Root Component

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/tanstack-start

Updates the `app/routes/__root.tsx` file to integrate React Query's `QueryClient` into the router context. This ensures that the `queryClient` is available globally within the TanStack Start application for data querying.

```typescript
import { QueryClient } from "@tanstack/react-query";
import { createRootRouteWithContext } from "@tanstack/react-router";
import { Outlet, Scripts, HeadContent } from "@tanstack/react-router";
import * as React from "react";

export const Route = createRootRouteWithContext<{
  queryClient: QueryClient;
}>()({
  head: () => ({
    meta: [
      {
        charSet: "utf-8",
      },
      {
        name: "viewport",
        content: "width=device-width, initial-scale=1",
      },
      {
        title: "TanStack Start Starter",
      },
    ],
  }),
  component: RootComponent,
});

function RootComponent() {
  return (
    <RootDocument>
      <Outlet />
    </RootDocument>
  );
}

function RootDocument({ children }: { children: React.ReactNode }) {
  return (
    <html>
      <head>
        <HeadContent />
      </head>
      <body>
        {children}
        <Scripts />
      </body>
    </html>
  );
}

```

--------------------------------

### Execute Agent Query via Convex Action

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/agents/getting-started

Define a Convex action that creates an agent thread, sends a prompt to the agent, and returns the generated text response. Requires proper component setup via npx convex dev to resolve type definitions.

```typescript
import { action } from "./_generated/server";
import { v } from "convex/values";

export const helloWorld = action({
  args: { city: v.string() },
  handler: async (ctx, { city }) => {
    const threadId = await createThread(ctx, components.agent);
    const prompt = `What is the weather in ${city}?`;
    const result = await agent.generateText(ctx, { threadId }, { prompt });
    return result.text;
  },
});
```

--------------------------------

### Integrate Convex Client into HTML Page with Script Tag

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/script-tag

An HTML document demonstrating the inclusion of the Convex client library via a `<script>` tag. It initializes `ConvexClient` with a development URL and sets up an `onUpdate` listener to log task data whenever the `tasks:get` query's results change.

```html
<!doctype html>
<script src="https://unpkg.com/convex@1.3.1/dist/browser.bundle.js"></script>
<script>
  const CONVEX_URL = "CONVEX_URL_GOES_HERE";
  const client = new convex.ConvexClient(CONVEX_URL);
  client.onUpdate("tasks:get", {}, (tasks) =>
    console.log(tasks.map((task) => task.text)),
  );
</script>
```

--------------------------------

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/vue

Initialize a new Vue project using the official Vue scaffolding tool. This command creates a new Vue application with TypeScript support as recommended for this quickstart.

```bash
npm create vue@latest my-vue-app
```

### Running the Convex RAG Example Application

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/agents/rag

These commands provide instructions on how to clone, set up, and run the complete Convex RAG example application from GitHub. This example showcases adding various content types, searching, generating text based on context, and introspecting document chunks, offering a practical demonstration of the described concepts.

```bash
git clone https://github.com/get-convex/rag.git
cd rag
npm run setup
npm run example
```

--------------------------------

### Connect Rust app to Convex backend and query data

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/rust

Configures a Rust application to connect to a Convex backend. It loads environment variables for the Convex deployment URL, initializes a `ConvexClient`, and then performs an asynchronous query to the `tasks:get` API endpoint, printing the result to the console.

```rust
use std::{
    collections::BTreeMap,
    env,
};

use convex::ConvexClient;

#[tokio::main]
async fn main() {
    dotenvy::from_filename(".env.local").ok();
    dotenvy::dotenv().ok();

    let deployment_url = env::var("CONVEX_URL").unwrap();

    let mut client = ConvexClient::new(&deployment_url).await.unwrap();
    let result = client.query("tasks:get", BTreeMap::new()).await.unwrap();
    println!("{result:#?}");
}
```

--------------------------------

### Verify Git Installation

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/tutorial

Command to verify that Git is installed on the system. Git is required for cloning the Convex tutorial repository and version control during development.

```bash
git -v
```

--------------------------------

### Create sample database data file

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/client/nextjs/pages-router/quickstart

Create a sampleData.jsonl file containing sample task records with text and completion status fields. Each line represents a separate JSON object to be imported into the database.

```json
{"text": "Buy groceries", "isCompleted": true}
{"text": "Go for a swim", "isCompleted": true}
{"text": "Integrate Convex", "isCompleted": false}
```

--------------------------------

### Setup and Test Convex Backend Functions with convex-test

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/testing/convex-test

This example demonstrates initializing a convex-test instance with schema and modules, then testing both empty and populated database states. It shows how to execute queries and mutations, verify return values, and validate data ordering using Vitest assertions.

```typescript
import { convexTest } from "convex-test";
import { describe, it, expect } from "vitest";
import { api, internal } from "./_generated/api";
import schema from "./schema";

describe("posts.list", () => {
  it("returns empty array when no posts exist", async () => {
    const t = convexTest(schema, modules);

    // Initially, there are no posts, so `list` returns an empty array
    const posts = await t.query(api.posts.list);
    expect(posts).toEqual([]);
  });

  it("returns all posts ordered by creation time when there are posts", async () => {
    const t = convexTest(schema, modules);

    // Create some posts
    await t.mutation(internal.posts.add, {
      title: "First Post",
      content: "This is the first post",
      author: "Alice"
    });
    await t.mutation(internal.posts.add, {
      title: "Second Post",
      content: "This is the second post",
      author: "Bob"
    });

    // `list` returns all posts ordered by creation time
    const posts = await t.query(api.posts.list);
    expect(posts).toHaveLength(2);
    expect(posts[0].title).toBe("Second Post");
    expect(posts[1].title).toBe("First Post");
  });
});

const modules = import.meta.glob("./**/*.ts");
```

--------------------------------

### Generate Example App Code and Deploy with Type Checking

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/components/authoring

Generates code for the example app and deploys it with optional type checking for components. This command should run last in the build sequence after the component has been built and is available for import by the example app.

```bash
npx convex dev --typecheck-components
```

```bash
node script.js
```

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/agents/playground

Starts the Playground UI locally using npm. The command reads the VITE_CONVEX_URL environment variable from .env.local to configure the deployment URL automatically.

```bash
npx @convex-dev/agent-playground
```

--------------------------------

### Define Agent with Language Model and Tools

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/agents/getting-started

Create an Agent instance with a name, language model (OpenAI GPT-4o-mini), system instructions, tools for function calling, and step limit. This agent can process complex queries by leveraging multiple tools and AI reasoning.

```typescript
import { components } from "./_generated/api";
import { Agent } from "@convex-dev/agent";
import { openai } from "@ai-sdk/openai";

const agent = new Agent(components.agent, {
  name: "My Agent",
  languageModel: openai.chat("gpt-4o-mini"),
  instructions: "You are a weather forecaster.",
  tools: { getWeather, getGeocoding },
  maxSteps: 3,
});
```

--------------------------------

### Create Nuxt application with npm

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/nuxt

Initialize a new Nuxt application using the npm create command. This creates the base project structure for a Nuxt application without optional modules.

```bash
npm create nuxt@latest my-nuxt-app
```

--------------------------------

### Expose a Convex Database Query in TypeScript

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/svelte

This TypeScript code defines an API query function named `get` within `src/convex/tasks.ts`. It retrieves all tasks from the `tasks` table in the Convex database and adds an `assigner` field to each task before returning the collection.

```typescript
import { query } from "./_generated/server";

export const get = query({
  args: {},
  handler: async (ctx) => {
    const tasks = await ctx.db.query("tasks").collect();
    return tasks.map((task) => ({ ...task, assigner: "tom" }));
  },
});
```

--------------------------------

### Connect React application to Convex backend

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/react

This `main.tsx` code initializes a `ConvexReactClient` using the Convex backend URL from environment variables. It then wraps the main `App` component with `ConvexProvider` to make the Convex client available throughout the React component tree.

```typescript
import React from "react";
import ReactDOM from "react-dom/client";
import App from "./App";
import "./index.css";
import { ConvexProvider, ConvexReactClient } from "convex/react";

const convex = new ConvexReactClient(import.meta.env.VITE_CONVEX_URL as string);

ReactDOM.createRoot(document.getElementById("root")!).render(
  <React.StrictMode>
    <ConvexProvider client={convex}>
      <App />
    </ConvexProvider>
  </React.StrictMode>,
);
```

--------------------------------

### Initialize Convex HTTP Router and Define a Root GET Route (TypeScript)

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/functions/http-actions

This snippet demonstrates the initial setup of the Convex `httpRouter`. It defines a basic GET route at the root path (`/`), where the handler uses `httpAction` to process the incoming `Request` and return a simple 'Hello from' `Response`, illustrating fundamental HTTP action handling.

```typescript
import { httpRouter } from "convex/server";
import { httpAction } from "./_generated/server";

const http = httpRouter();

http.route({
  path: "/",
  method: "GET",
  handler: httpAction(async (ctx, request) => {
    return new Response(`Hello from ${request.url}`);
  }),
});
export default http;
```

--------------------------------

### Create Next.js App with npx

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/nextjs

Initialize a new Next.js project using create-next-app command. This sets up a fresh Next.js application with default configuration suitable for Convex integration.

```bash
npx create-next-app@latest my-app
```

--------------------------------

### Define Convex backend query function to fetch tasks (JavaScript)

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/python

This JavaScript code defines and exports a Convex query function named 'get' within 'convex/tasks.js'. This function retrieves all documents from the 'tasks' table in the database and makes them accessible to clients via an API endpoint like 'tasks:get'.

```javascript
import { query } from "./_generated/server";

export const get = query({
  args: {},
  handler: async ({ db }) => {
    return await db.query("tasks").collect();
  }
});
```

--------------------------------

### GET BaseTableReader.query()

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/api/interfaces/server.BaseTableReader

Begin a query for the table. Queries don't execute immediately, so calling this method and extending its query are free until the results are actually used. Returns a QueryInitializer object to start building a query.

```APIDOC
## GET BaseTableReader.query()

### Description
Begin a query for the table. This method initializes a query builder that allows you to construct complex queries with filters, sorting, and pagination. Queries are lazy-evaluated and don't execute until results are consumed.

### Method
GET

### Signature
```typescript
query(): QueryInitializer<NamedTableInfo<DataModel, TableName>>
```

### Parameters
None

### Returns
- **QueryInitializer<NamedTableInfo<DataModel, TableName>>** - A QueryInitializer object to start building a query. Queries don't execute immediately, so calling this method and extending its query are free until the results are actually used.

### Response Example
```typescript
// Returns a QueryInitializer object
const queryBuilder = table.query();
// Query execution is deferred until results are consumed
```

### Type Parameters
- **DataModel** - extends GenericDataModel
- **TableName** - extends TableNamesInDataModel<DataModel>

### Notes
- Query construction is free and lazy-evaluated
- Actual database execution occurs only when results are accessed
- Use QueryInitializer methods to add filters, sorting, and pagination

### Defined in
server/database.ts:100
```

--------------------------------

### Import sample data to Convex database

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/client/nextjs/pages-router/quickstart

Use the Convex import command to load sample data from the sampleData.jsonl file into a new tasks table in your Convex database.

```bash
npx convex import --table tasks sampleData.jsonl
```

--------------------------------

### Create a new React Native Expo project

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/react-native

This command initializes a new React Native project named 'my-app' using Expo CLI. It sets up the basic project structure and dependencies required for a React Native application.

```bash
npx create-expo-app my-app
```

--------------------------------

### Get URL for Convex Storage File in JavaScript

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/api/interfaces/server.StorageWriter

This example demonstrates how to retrieve the public URL for a file stored in Convex using its `storageId`. The `ctx.storage.getUrl` method returns a Promise that resolves to the file's URL or `null` if not found. The URL can then be used to fetch the file via HTTP GET.

```javascript
const url = await ctx.storage.getUrl(storageId);
```

--------------------------------

### Configure Convex Agent Component

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/agents/getting-started

Set up the convex.config.ts file to register the agent component in your Convex project. This configuration must be created in the convex/ folder and run via npx convex dev to generate required type definitions.

```typescript
// convex/convex.config.ts
import { defineApp } from "convex/server";
import agent from "@convex-dev/agent/convex.config";

const app = defineApp();
app.use(agent);

export default app;
```

--------------------------------

### Query Constructor - Basic Example

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/functions/query-functions

Demonstrates how to define a basic query using the query constructor function. This example shows a simple query that returns a constant string without any arguments.

```APIDOC
## Query Constructor

### Description
Define a basic query using the `query` constructor function from the Convex server module.

### Method
GET (conceptually - queries are read operations)

### Endpoint
api.myFunctions.myConstantString

### Parameters
#### Query Arguments
- None for this example

### Request Example
```typescript
import { query } from "./_generated/server";

export const myConstantString = query({
  args: {},
  handler: () => {
    return "My never changing string";
  },
});
```

### Response
#### Success Response
- **result** (string) - The constant string value returned by the query

#### Response Example
```
"My never changing string"
```
```

--------------------------------

### Configure package.json for Nuxt and Convex

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/nuxt

Set up package.json with development scripts and dependencies for Nuxt and Convex integration. The dev script includes the --dotenv .env.local flag to use Convex environment variables.

```json
{
  "name": "nuxt-app",
  "private": true,
  "type": "module",
  "scripts": {
    "build": "nuxt build",
    "dev": "nuxt dev --dotenv .env.local",
    "generate": "nuxt generate",
    "preview": "nuxt preview",
    "postinstall": "nuxt prepare"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "convex": "^1.25.2",
    "convex-nuxt": "^0.1.3",
    "nuxt": "^3.17.6",
    "vue": "^3.5.17",
    "vue-router": "^4.5.1"
  }
}
```

--------------------------------

### Install NPM Dependencies

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/chef

Install all required Node.js dependencies for the Convex project. This command reads the package.json file and installs all listed packages and their dependencies.

```bash
npm i
```

--------------------------------

### Connect Node.js Script to Convex Backend

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/nodejs

Initializes a `ConvexHttpClient` using the Convex development URL loaded from environment variables. It then performs a one-time query to fetch and log the task data using the defined Convex API function.

```javascript
import { ConvexHttpClient } from "convex/browser";
import { api } from "./convex/_generated/api.js";
import * as dotenv from "dotenv";
dotenv.config({ path: ".env.local" });

const client = new ConvexHttpClient(process.env["CONVEX_URL"]);

client.query(api.tasks.get).then(console.log);
```

--------------------------------

### Install Clerk Next.js SDK via npm

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/auth/clerk

Command to install the Clerk Next.js SDK package. Required for integrating Clerk authentication into Next.js applications. Should be run in a separate terminal window after Convex configuration is deployed.

```bash
npm install @clerk/nextjs
```

--------------------------------

### Setup React App with ConvexProviderWithAuth0

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/auth/auth0

Configure the main React entry point with Auth0Provider wrapping ConvexProviderWithAuth0. Enables Auth0 authentication with Convex client and includes refresh token caching. Requires domain and clientId from Auth0 settings and VITE_CONVEX_URL environment variable.

```TypeScript
import React from "react";
import ReactDOM from "react-dom/client";
import App from "./App";
import "./index.css";
import { ConvexReactClient } from "convex/react";
import { ConvexProviderWithAuth0 } from "convex/react-auth0";
import { Auth0Provider } from "@auth0/auth0-react";

const convex = new ConvexReactClient(import.meta.env.VITE_CONVEX_URL as string);

ReactDOM.createRoot(document.getElementById("root")!).render(
  <React.StrictMode>
    <Auth0Provider
      domain="your-domain.us.auth0.com"
      clientId="yourclientid"
      authorizationParams={{
        redirect_uri: window.location.origin,
      }}
      useRefreshTokens={true}
      cacheLocation="localstorage"
    >
      <ConvexProviderWithAuth0 client={convex}>
        <App />
      </ConvexProviderWithAuth0>
    </Auth0Provider>
  </React.StrictMode>,
);
```

--------------------------------

### Create sample data JSONL file

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/swift

Create a sampleData.jsonl file containing todo items with text and completion status. This file will be imported into the Convex database to populate the initial tasks table.

```jsonl
{"text": "Buy groceries", "isCompleted": true}
{"text": "Go for a swim", "isCompleted": true}
{"text": "Integrate Convex", "isCompleted": false}
```

--------------------------------

### Create Python virtual environment

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/python

This command creates a virtual environment named 'venv' inside the 'my-app' directory using Python 3. Virtual environments help isolate project dependencies.

```bash
python3 -m venv my-app/venv
```

--------------------------------

### Setup ClerkProvider and ConvexProviderWithClerk in React

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/auth/clerk

React entry point configuration that initializes both Clerk and Convex providers. The ClerkProvider wraps ConvexProviderWithClerk, which receives the Convex client and Clerk's useAuth hook. This setup enables authentication context and Convex query/mutation capabilities throughout the application.

```TypeScript
import React from "react";
import ReactDOM from "react-dom/client";
import App from "./App";
import "./index.css";
import { ClerkProvider, useAuth } from "@clerk/clerk-react";
import { ConvexProviderWithClerk } from "convex/react-clerk";
import { ConvexReactClient } from "convex/react";

const convex = new ConvexReactClient(import.meta.env.VITE_CONVEX_URL as string);

ReactDOM.createRoot(document.getElementById("root")!).render(
  <React.StrictMode>
    <ClerkProvider publishableKey="pk_test_...">
      <ConvexProviderWithClerk client={convex} useAuth={useAuth}>
        <App />
      </ConvexProviderWithClerk>
    </ClerkProvider>
  </React.StrictMode>,
);
```

--------------------------------

### Use NPM Packages in Query

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/functions/query-functions

Demonstrates importing and using NPM packages within Convex queries. Example uses the @faker-js/faker package to generate random data. Requires package installation via npm and compatibility with Convex runtime.

```TypeScript
import { query } from "./_generated/server";
import { faker } from "@faker-js/faker";

export const randomName = query({
  args: {},
  handler: () => {
    faker.seed();
    return faker.person.fullName();
  },
});
```

--------------------------------

### Initialize Convex Project with AuthKit Template

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/auth/authkit/auto-provision

This command initializes a new Convex project using the latest CLI, guiding the user to select an AuthKit-enabled template. The chosen template includes a `convex.json` file that automatically configures an AuthKit environment upon deployment, simplifying the setup of WorkOS authentication for the project.

```bash
npm create convex@latest
```

--------------------------------

### Create and Configure HttpRouter with Routes

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/api/classes/server.HttpRouter

Demonstrates how to initialize an HttpRouter, define HTTP actions inline and by import, and export the router as default. Shows both POST and GET request handling with path and method specifications.

```javascript
import { httpRouter } from "convex/server";
import { getMessagesByAuthor } from "./getMessagesByAuthor";
import { httpAction } from "./_generated/server";

const http = httpRouter();

// HTTP actions can be defined inline...
http.route({
  path: "/message",
  method: "POST",
  handler: httpAction(async ({ runMutation }, request) => {
    const { author, body } = await request.json();

    await runMutation(api.sendMessage.default, { body, author });
    return new Response(null, {
      status: 200,
    });
  })
});

// ...or they can be imported from other files.
http.route({
  path: "/getMessagesByAuthor",
  method: "GET",
  handler: getMessagesByAuthor,
});

// Convex expects the router to be the default export of `convex/http.js`.
export default http;
```

--------------------------------

### Initialize ConvexClient in Swift

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/swift

Create a ConvexClient instance with your Convex deployment URL. This client handles communication between your Swift app and the Convex backend. Place this near the top of your ContentView file.

```swift
import SwiftUI
import ConvexMobile

let convex = ConvexClient(deploymentUrl: "YOUR_CONVEX_URL")

struct ContentView: View {
  // ...
}
```

--------------------------------

### Install Convex CLI using npm

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/cli

This command installs the Convex command-line interface globally or locally using npm. It provides access to various Convex project management and function interaction tools.

```bash
npm install convex
```

--------------------------------

### Start Convex MCP Server for a specific project directory

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/ai/convex-mcp-server

This command starts the Convex MCP server, explicitly binding it to a single project directory specified by `--project-dir`. This is useful for scenarios where the server should only operate within the context of a particular Convex project, rather than supporting multiple projects.

```bash
npx -y convex@latest mcp start --project-dir /path/to/project
```

--------------------------------

### Use Suspense Query with Convex in TanStack Start

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/client/tanstack/tanstack-start

Demonstrates how to use `useSuspenseQuery()` to render Convex queries on the server with live updates on the client. This is the simplest approach for server-side rendering Convex queries in TanStack Start while maintaining client-side reactivity.

```TypeScript
const { data } = useSuspenseQuery(convexQuery(api.messages.list, {}));
```

--------------------------------

### Import sample data into Convex database

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/swift

Import the sampleData.jsonl file into a tasks table in your Convex database. Run this command in a terminal from your Swift project directory.

```bash
npx convex import --table tasks sampleData.jsonl
```

--------------------------------

### Create TanStack Start Route with Loader for Convex Queries

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/client/tanstack/tanstack-start

Shows how to add a loader to a TanStack Start route that prefetches Convex query data before navigation. Loaders run on hover by default, making client-side navigations faster by ensuring data is already loaded in the query cache.

```TypeScript
export const Route = createFileRoute('/posts')({
  loader: async (opts) => {
    await opts.context.queryClient.ensureQueryData(
      convexQuery(api.messages.list, {}),
    );
  },
  component: () => {
    const { data } = useSuspenseQuery(convexQuery(api.messages.list, {}));
    return (
      <div>
        {data.map((message) => (
          <Message key={message.id} post={message} />
        ))}
      </div>
    );
  },
})
```

--------------------------------

### GET /list_log_streams

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/deployment-api/list-log-streams

This endpoint retrieves the configurations for all log streams currently deployed. It provides an overview of the logging setup within the deployment.

```APIDOC
## GET /list_log_streams

### Description
List configs for all existing log streams in a deployment.

### Method
GET

### Endpoint
/list_log_streams

### Parameters
#### Path Parameters
(None)

#### Query Parameters
(None)

#### Request Body
(None)

### Request Example
{}

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
- **id** (string) - Unique identifier for the log stream.
- **name** (string) - User-defined name of the log stream.
- **status** (string) - Current status of the log stream (e.g., "active", "inactive", "error").
- **destination** (string) - The destination of the log stream (e.g., "AWS CloudWatch", "Local File").
- **createdAt** (string) - Timestamp when the log stream was created (ISO 8601 format).

#### Response Example
[
  {
    "id": "ls_123abc",
    "name": "ApplicationLogs",
    "status": "active",
    "destination": "AWS CloudWatch",
    "createdAt": "2023-10-27T10:00:00Z"
  },
  {
    "id": "ls_456def",
    "name": "DatabaseLogs",
    "status": "inactive",
    "destination": "Local File",
    "createdAt": "2023-10-26T15:30:00Z"
  }
]
```

--------------------------------

### Start Convex MCP Server using npx

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/ai/convex-mcp-server

This command initiates the Convex Model Context Protocol (MCP) server using `npx`. It starts the server, allowing AI agents to interact with your Convex deployment by providing various tools and functionalities.

```bash
npx -y convex@latest mcp start
```

--------------------------------

### Retrieve Convex Storage File Metadata using System Table in JavaScript

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/api/interfaces/server.StorageWriter

This example shows the recommended way to get metadata for a file stored in Convex. Instead of using `ctx.storage.getMetadata` (which is deprecated), it directly queries the `_storage` system table using `ctx.db.system.get` with the `storageId`. The returned object includes file details like `_id`, `_creationTime`, `sha256`, `size`, and optional `contentType`.

```javascript
const metadata = await ctx.db.system.get("_storage", storageId);
// { _id, _creationTime, sha256, size, contentType? }
```

--------------------------------

### Example audit_log push_config Event Schema in JSON

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/production/integrations/log-streams

This JSON example demonstrates an `audit_log` event specifically for a `push_config` action within a Convex deployment. It includes the event topic, timestamp, the specific action performed, and a stringified JSON `audit_log_metadata` field containing details about the configuration changes. This event provides a record of significant deployment modifications.

```json
{
  "topic": "audit_log",
  "timestamp": 1714421999886,
  "audit_log_action": "push_config",
  "audit_log_metadata": "{\"auth\":{\"added\":[],\"removed\":[]},\"crons\":{\"added\":[],\"deleted\":[],\"updated\":[]},..."
}
```

--------------------------------

### Initialize MainActivity with Convex Client

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/android

Kotlin MainActivity onCreate method that initializes ConvexClient with the deployment URL and sets up the Compose UI hierarchy with Scaffold and Tasks composable.

```kotlin
override fun onCreate(savedInstanceState: Bundle?) {
    super.onCreate(savedInstanceState)
    enableEdgeToEdge()
    setContent {
        ConvexQuickstartTheme {
            Scaffold(modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize()) { innerPadding ->
                Tasks(
                    client = ConvexClient($YOUR_CONVEX_URL),
                    modifier = Modifier.padding(innerPadding)
                )
            }
        }
    }
}
```

--------------------------------

### Convex Object Type Example and Validation in JavaScript

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/database/types

Provides an example of a plain JavaScript object suitable for Convex, which includes all enumerable properties. The validation is performed using `v.object({property: value})`. Objects can have at most 1024 entries, with field names being non-empty and not starting with '$' or '_'.

```javascript
{a: "abc"}
```

```javascript
v.object({property: value})
```

### Create a new Rust Cargo project

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/rust

Initializes a new Rust project using Cargo, the Rust package manager, and then navigates into the newly created project directory. This command sets up the basic file structure required for a Rust application.

```bash
cargo new my_app
cd my_app
```

--------------------------------

### Configure Root Layout with Convex Provider

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/nextjs

Integrate ConvexClientProvider into the root layout file to wrap all child components. This ensures the Convex context is available throughout the entire application.

```typescript
import type { Metadata } from "next";
import { Geist, Geist_Mono } from "next/font/google";
import "./globals.css";
import { ConvexClientProvider } from "./ConvexClientProvider";

const geistSans = Geist({
  variable: "--font-geist-sans",
  subsets: ["latin"],
});

const geistMono = Geist_Mono({
  variable: "--font-geist-mono",
  subsets: ["latin"],
});

export const metadata: Metadata = {
  title: "Create Next App",
  description: "Generated by create next app",
};

export default function RootLayout({
  children,
}: Readonly<{
  children: React.ReactNode;
}>) {
  return (
    <html lang="en">
      <body
        className={`${geistSans.variable} ${geistMono.variable} antialiased`}
      >
        <ConvexClientProvider>{children}</ConvexClientProvider>
      </body>
    </html>
  );
}
```

--------------------------------

### Seed Convex Preview Deployment (Vercel CI/CD Example)

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/database/import-export/import

This advanced example illustrates how to seed a Convex preview deployment within a Vercel CI/CD pipeline. It involves deploying the application, checking the Vercel environment type, and conditionally importing data using the --preview-name flag based on the Git commit reference.

```bash
npx convex deploy --cmd 'npm run build' &&
if [ "$VERCEL_ENV" == "preview" ]; then
npx convex import --preview-name "$VERCEL_GIT_COMMIT_REF" seed_data.zip;
fi
```

--------------------------------

### Set up ConvexProvider in Next.js pages app

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/client/nextjs/pages-router/quickstart

Initialize a ConvexReactClient with your deployment URL and wrap the entire app with ConvexProvider in pages/_app.js. This enables all child components to access Convex hooks like useQuery.

```javascript
import "@/styles/globals.css";
import { ConvexProvider, ConvexReactClient } from "convex/react";

const convex = new ConvexReactClient(process.env.NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL);

export default function App({ Component, pageProps }) {
  return (
    <ConvexProvider client={convex}>
      <Component {...pageProps} />
    </ConvexProvider>
  );
}
```

--------------------------------

### Initialize Convex Client in SvelteKit Layout

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/svelte

This Svelte component code for `src/routes/+layout.svelte` initializes the Convex client using `setupConvex` and the `PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL`. By placing it in the layout, the Convex client becomes available globally across all pages in the SvelteKit application.

```svelte
<script lang="ts">
	import { PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL } from '$env/static/public';
	import { setupConvex } from 'convex-svelte';

	const { children } = $props();
	setupConvex(PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL);
</script>

{@render children()}
```

--------------------------------

### Import sample data into Convex database

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/react-native

Use the `convex import` command to load the data from `sampleData.jsonl` into a new `tasks` table within the Convex database. This command populates the backend with initial data for the application.

```bash
npx convex import --table tasks sampleData.jsonl
```

--------------------------------

### Display Convex Query Results with TanStack React Query

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/tanstack-start

Renders task data fetched from Convex using the useSuspenseQuery hook from TanStack React Query. The component initially renders on the server with SSR, then updates live in the browser as data changes. Maps through task array to display each task's text content with unique key identifiers.

```typescript
import { convexQuery } from "@convex-dev/react-query";
import { useSuspenseQuery } from "@tanstack/react-query";
import { createFileRoute } from "@tanstack/react-router";
import { api } from "../../convex/_generated/api";

export const Route = createFileRoute("/")({
  component: Home,
});

function Home() {
  const { data } = useSuspenseQuery(convexQuery(api.tasks.get, {}));

  return (
    <div>
      {data.map(({ _id, text }) => (
        <div key={_id}>{text}</div>
      ))}
    </div>
  );
}
```

--------------------------------

### Query and display tasks with useQuery hook

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/client/nextjs/pages-router/quickstart

Use the useQuery hook in pages/index.js to fetch tasks from the Convex backend and render them as a list. The hook automatically handles loading and error states, returning undefined during initial load.

```javascript
import { useQuery } from "convex/react";
import { api } from "../convex/_generated/api";

export default function Home() {
  const tasks = useQuery(api.tasks.get);
  return (
    <main className="flex min-h-screen flex-col items-center p-24">
      {tasks?.map(({ _id, text }) => (
        <div key={_id}>{text}</div>
      ))}
    </main>
  );
}
```

--------------------------------

### Example current_storage_usage Event Schema in JSON

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/production/integrations/log-streams

This JSON example illustrates the structure and typical values for a `current_storage_usage` event emitted by Convex. It details the various storage metrics, including document, index, vector, file, and backup storage sizes in bytes. This event helps in monitoring deployment resource consumption and calculating billing costs.

```json
{
  "topic": "current_storage_usage",
  "timestamp": 1715973841548,
  "total_document_size_bytes": 104857600,
  "total_index_size_bytes": 10485760,
  "total_vector_storage_bytes": 5242880,
  "total_file_storage_bytes": 52428800,
  "total_backup_storage_bytes": 209715200
}
```

--------------------------------

### Define AuthConfig for Convex Authentication

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/api/modules/server

Exports an AuthConfig object that configures authentication providers for your Convex project. This configuration is defined in auth.config.ts and specifies OAuth/OIDC providers with domain and application ID. The example shows a basic provider setup that must satisfy the AuthConfig type.

```typescript
import { AuthConfig } from "convex/server";

export default {
  providers: [
    {
      domain: "https://your.issuer.url.com",
      applicationID: "your-application-id",
    },
  ],
} satisfies AuthConfig;
```

--------------------------------

### Start Convex MCP Server with production deployment access

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/ai/convex-mcp-server

This command starts the Convex MCP server, enabling it to access and potentially modify production deployments. The `--dangerously-enable-production-deployments` flag bypasses a safety measure, so it should be used with extreme caution and only when direct interaction with production data is required.

```bash
npx -y convex@latest mcp start --dangerously-enable-production-deployments
```

--------------------------------

### Configure Android Manifest with Internet Permission

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/android

XML configuration for AndroidManifest.xml that declares the INTERNET permission required for network communication with Convex backend services.

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<manifest xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    xmlns:tools="http://schemas.android.com/tools">
    <uses-permission android:name="android.permission.INTERNET"/>
    <application>
        <!-- ... existing application contents -->
    </application>
</manifest>
```

--------------------------------

### Query and Display Data in Vue Component

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/vue

Use the useConvexQuery composable to fetch tasks from the Convex backend and display them in a Vue template with loading state handling and conditional rendering based on completion status.

```vue
<script setup lang="ts">
import { useConvexQuery } from "convex-vue";
import { api } from "../convex/_generated/api";

const { data, isPending } = useConvexQuery(api.tasks.get);
</script>

<template>
  <span v-if="isPending"> Loading... </span>
  <ul v-else>
    <li v-for="todo in data">
      {{ todo.text }} {{ todo.isCompleted ? "" : "" }}
    </li>
  </ul>
</template>
```

--------------------------------

### Install NPM Package for Query Usage

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/functions/query-functions

Command to install the @faker-js/faker NPM package into node_modules for use within Convex queries. Package must be compatible with Convex runtime.

```bash
npm install @faker-js/faker
```

--------------------------------

### Performing Range Queries with a Compound Author-Title Index in Convex

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/database/reading-data/indexes/indexes-and-query-perf

This example illustrates how a compound index can be used for efficient range queries. It finds all books by a specific author where the title starts with a certain letter, demonstrating how `gte` and `lt` operations on indexed fields can significantly narrow down the search space and improve performance.

```javascript
const asimovBooksStartingWithF = await ctx.db
  .query("books")
  .withIndex("by_author_title", (q) =>
    q.eq("author", "Isaac Asimov").gte("title", "F").lt("title", "G"),
  )
  .collect();
```

--------------------------------

### Define Convex Database Schema with defineSchema and defineTable (TypeScript)

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/api/modules/server

This TypeScript example demonstrates how to define a Convex database schema. It utilizes `defineSchema` as the default export from `convex/schema.ts` and `defineTable` to specify individual tables like `users`, `messages`, `channels`, and `results`. The example illustrates field definitions using `v.string()`, `v.id()`, `v.number()`, and `v.literal()`, as well as creating indexes and defining a discriminated union table. This setup provides runtime validation and end-to-end TypeScript type safety for your Convex project.

```typescript
// convex/schema.ts
import { defineSchema, defineTable } from "convex/server";
import { v } from "convex/values";

export default defineSchema({
  users: defineTable({
    name: v.string(),
    email: v.string(),
  }).index("by_email", ["email"]),

  messages: defineTable({
    body: v.string(),
    userId: v.id("users"),
    channelId: v.id("channels"),
  }).index("by_channel", ["channelId"]),

  channels: defineTable({
    name: v.string(),
  }),

  // Discriminated union table:
  results: defineTable(
    v.union(
      v.object({ kind: v.literal("error"), message: v.string() }),
      v.object({ kind: v.literal("success"), value: v.number() }),
    )
  ),
});
```

--------------------------------

### Create Convex React Client Provider Component

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/nextjs

Create a client component that initializes ConvexReactClient with the deployment URL and wraps the app with ConvexProvider. This enables client-side data fetching and state management throughout the application.

```typescript
"use client";

import { ConvexProvider, ConvexReactClient } from "convex/react";
import { ReactNode } from "react";

const convex = new ConvexReactClient(process.env.NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL!);

export function ConvexClientProvider({ children }: { children: ReactNode }) {
  return <ConvexProvider client={convex}>{children}</ConvexProvider>;
}
```

--------------------------------

### Illustrating Deterministic `Math.random()` and `Date.now()` in Convex

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/functions/runtimes

This JavaScript example demonstrates the deterministic behavior of `Math.random()` and `Date.now()` within Convex functions. Variables initialized globally (`globalRand`, `globalNow`) are frozen at deployment time. Inside a mutation, `Date.now()` is frozen at the function's start, and `Math.random()` generates unique values for each call during a single function execution.

```javascript
const globalRand = Math.random(); // `globalRand` does not change between runs.
const globalNow = Date.now(); // `globalNow` is the time when Convex functions were deployed.

export const updateSomething = mutation({
  args: {},
  handler: () => {
    const now1 = Date.now(); // `now1` is the time when the function execution started.
    const rand1 = Math.random(); // `rand1` has a new value for each function run.
    // implementation
    const now2 = Date.now(); // `now2` === `now1`
    const rand2 = Math.random(); // `rand1` !== `rand2`
  },
});
```

--------------------------------

### Start Convex dev deployment

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/bun

Initialize the Convex development environment which handles GitHub authentication, project creation, and creates a convex/ folder for backend API functions. The command continues running to sync functions with the cloud deployment.

```bash
bunx convex dev
```

--------------------------------

### Create Next.js app with create-next-app

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/client/nextjs/pages-router/quickstart

Initialize a new Next.js application with the Pages Router using the create-next-app command-line tool. This command creates a basic Next.js project structure with default configuration options.

```bash
npx create-next-app@latest my-app --no-app --js
```

--------------------------------

### Validator Builder - Usage Example

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/api/modules/values

Practical example demonstrating how to use the validator builder in a Convex mutation function. Shows how to define validators for function arguments and return values, including optional fields and ID validators.

```APIDOC
## Using Validators in Convex Functions

### Description
Example of using the validator builder to validate function arguments and return values in a Convex mutation.

### Code Example

```javascript
import { v } from "convex/values";

// Use in function definition:
export const createUser = mutation({
  args: {
    name: v.string(),
    email: v.string(),
    age: v.optional(v.number()),
  },
  returns: v.id("users"),
  handler: async (ctx, args) => {
    return await ctx.db.insert("users", args);
  },
});
```

### Explanation

#### Arguments Validation
- **name** (string) - Required - User's full name
- **email** (string) - Required - User's email address
- **age** (number) - Optional - User's age

#### Return Value
- **returns: v.id("users")** - Function returns a document ID from the users table

### Best Practices

1. Always include `args` validator on all Convex functions
2. Always include `returns` validator on all Convex functions
3. If a function doesn't return a value, use `returns: v.null()`
4. Use `v.optional()` for fields that may not be provided
5. Use `v.id("tableName")` when returning or validating document IDs

### Related Documentation

- Database Types: https://docs.convex.dev/database/types
- Function Validation: https://docs.convex.dev/functions/validation
```

--------------------------------

### Preview Deploy Key Format

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/cli/deploy-key-types

Example format of a preview deploy key used to deploy to preview branches instead of production. This key type allows normal convex deploy commands to target preview deployments for testing.

```text
preview:team-slug:project-slug|eyJ2...0=
```

--------------------------------

### Project Token Format

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/cli/deploy-key-types

Example format of a project token that grants total control over a project and permissions to create and manage development and production deployments. Project tokens are obtained through Convex OAuth applications.

```text
project:team-slug:project-slug|eyJ2...0=
```

--------------------------------

### Manage user authentication states with Convex React helper components

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/auth/auth0

This example illustrates the use of `Authenticated`, `Unauthenticated`, and `AuthLoading` components provided by `convex/react`. These helper components abstract away the conditional rendering logic based on the `useConvexAuth` hook, offering a declarative way to display different UI states for authenticated, unauthenticated, or loading users.

```typescript
import { Authenticated, Unauthenticated, AuthLoading } from "convex/react";

function App() {
  return (
    <div className="App">
      <Authenticated>Logged in</Authenticated>
      <Unauthenticated>Logged out</Unauthenticated>
      <AuthLoading>Still loading</AuthLoading>
    </div>
  );
}
```

--------------------------------

### Set Up ConvexProvider in Vue Main Entry

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/vue

Configure the Convex Vue plugin in the main application entry point to make the Convex client available throughout the Vue application. The VITE_CONVEX_URL environment variable is set during the dev initialization.

```typescript
import { convexVue } from 'convex-vue'
import { createApp } from 'vue'
import App from './App.vue'

const app = createApp(App)

app.use(convexVue, {
  url: import.meta.env.VITE_CONVEX_URL,
})

app.mount('#app')
```

--------------------------------

### Query and Display Data with useQuery Hook

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/nextjs

Use the useQuery hook from Convex/React to fetch tasks from the api.tasks.get endpoint and render them as a list. This client component demonstrates data fetching and rendering in Next.js with Convex.

```typescript
"use client";

import Image from "next/image";
import { useQuery } from "convex/react";
import { api } from "../convex/_generated/api";

export default function Home() {
  const tasks = useQuery(api.tasks.get);
  return (
    <main className="flex min-h-screen flex-col items-center justify-between p-24">
      {tasks?.map(({ _id, text }) => <div key={_id}>{text}</div>)}
    </main>
  );
}
```

--------------------------------

### Generate type-safe client using OpenAPI Generator CLI

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/client/open-api

This set of commands first installs the `openapi-generator-cli` tool globally or locally, then uses it to generate a type-safe client from the `convex-spec.yaml` file. The example specifies generating a Go client (`-g go`) and outputs the generated code into a directory named `convex_client` (`-o convex_client`). This process creates client-side code that can interact with the Convex API in a strongly typed manner.

```shell
npm i openapi-generator-cli
npx openapi-generator-cli generate -i convex-spec.yaml -g go -o convex_client
```

--------------------------------

### Configure Multiple HTTP Routes with Convex HttpRouter (TypeScript)

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/functions/http-actions

This code demonstrates how to configure and expose multiple HTTP action handlers through the `httpRouter`. It maps specific paths and HTTP methods (POST, GET) to predefined action functions, including an example of using `pathPrefix` for flexible routing. The `http` router instance is then exported as the default, making these routes available.

```typescript
import { httpRouter } from "convex/server";
import { postMessage, getByAuthor, getByAuthorPathSuffix } from "./messages";

const http = httpRouter();

http.route({
  path: "/postMessage",
  method: "POST",
  handler: postMessage,
});

// Define additional routes
http.route({
  path: "/getMessagesByAuthor",
  method: "GET",
  handler: getByAuthor,
});

// Define a route using a path prefix
http.route({
  // Will match /getAuthorMessages/User+123 and /getAuthorMessages/User+234 etc.
  pathPrefix: "/getAuthorMessages/",
  method: "GET",
  handler: getByAuthorPathSuffix,
});

// Convex expects the router to be the default export of `convex/http.js`.
export default http;
```

--------------------------------

### Debugging HTTP Actions - Step-by-Step Guide

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/functions/http-actions

Comprehensive debugging process for troubleshooting HTTP actions in Convex. This guide walks through verifying deployment, testing with curl, and diagnosing browser-based request issues including CORS problems.

```APIDOC
## HTTP Actions - Debugging

### Step 1: Verify HTTP Actions Deployment

#### Description
Confirm that HTTP actions have been properly deployed to your Convex backend.

#### Steps
1. Navigate to the [functions page](https://dashboard.convex.dev/deployment/functions) in the Convex dashboard
2. Verify there is an entry called `http`
3. If missing, verify:
   - HTTP actions are defined with `httpRouter` in file named `http.js` or `http.ts`
   - Run `npx convex dev` and confirm no errors are present

---

### Step 2: Test Endpoint with curl

#### Description
Verify HTTP endpoint accessibility using curl command-line tool.

#### Instructions
1. Get deployment URL from dashboard Settings > URL and Deploy Key
2. Ensure URL ends in `.convex.site` (not `.convex.cloud`)
   - Example: `https://happy-animal-123.convex.site`
3. Execute curl command:

#### Request Example
```
curl -X GET https://<deployment-name>.convex.site/myEndpoint
```

#### Verification
- Check the [logs page](https://dashboard.convex.dev/deployment/logs) in dashboard
- Confirm HTTP action entry appears in logs

---

### Step 3: Inspect Browser Network Requests

#### Description
Diagnose issues when HTTP actions are deployed and curl-accessible but fail from browser.

#### Steps
1. Open browser Developer Tools and go to Network tab
2. Trigger HTTP requests from your application
3. Verify request URL:
   - Ends in `.convex.site`
   - Contains correct deployment name
4. Check [logs page](https://dashboard.convex.dev/deployment/logs) for request entries

#### CORS Issues
- **Error**: "CORS error" or "Access to fetch at '...' has been blocked by CORS policy"
- **Solution**: Configure CORS headers and add handler for pre-flight `OPTIONS` request

#### Common Issues
- URL mismatch between curl test and browser request
- Incorrect deployment name in URL
- Missing CORS configuration
```

--------------------------------

### Install Convex test dependencies with npm

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/testing/convex-test

Install Vitest, convex-test library, and edge-runtime VM for testing Convex functions. These dependencies enable running Convex functions in a test environment that matches the production runtime.

```bash
npm install --save-dev convex-test vitest @edge-runtime/vm
```

--------------------------------

### POST /api/processPayment (Convex Action Example)

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/api/interfaces/server.GenericActionCtx

An example Convex action demonstrating how to process a payment. This action uses the `GenericActionCtx` to read data via `ctx.runQuery`, interact with an external payment API, and update the database using `ctx.runMutation`.

```APIDOC
## POST /api/processPayment (Convex Action Example)

### Description
This Convex action processes a payment for a given order. It demonstrates how to use `ctx.runQuery` to read data, interact with an external payment API (e.g., Stripe), and `ctx.runMutation` to update the database within an action function.

### Method
POST

### Endpoint
/api/processPayment (Conceptual endpoint for a Convex action)

### Parameters
#### Request Body
- **orderId** (string, ID of "orders") - Required - The ID of the order to process.
- **amount** (number) - Required - The amount to charge for the order.

### Request Example
{
  "orderId": "order_abc123",
  "amount": 100.50
}

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
- **null** (null) - Indicates successful processing without returning specific data.

#### Response Example
null
```

--------------------------------

### Install Convex Helpers npm package

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/client/open-api

This command installs the `convex-helpers` npm package, which provides command-line interface (CLI) tools necessary for Convex development, including the functionality to generate OpenAPI specifications. It is a prerequisite for the subsequent steps in the OpenAPI generation workflow.

```shell
npm install convex-helpers
```

--------------------------------

### Launch Convex development server

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/auth/authkit

Navigate to the project directory and start the development server. This command runs the application in development mode for local testing and development.

```bash
cd my-app
npm run dev
```

--------------------------------

### Configure Convex URL in nuxt.config.ts

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/nuxt

Set up Convex configuration in the Nuxt config file by adding the Convex URL from environment variables. This enables the application to connect to the Convex backend.

```typescript
export default defineNuxtConfig({
  compatibilityDate: '2025-07-15',
  devtools: { enabled: true },
  modules: ['convex-nuxt'],
  convex: {
    url: process.env.CONVEX_URL
  },
})
```

--------------------------------

### Import Statements for Android Compose and Convex Integration

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/android

Complete set of Kotlin import statements required for the MainActivity implementation, including Android system libraries, Jetpack Compose UI components, and Convex client functionality.

```kotlin
import android.os.Bundle
import androidx.activity.ComponentActivity
import androidx.activity.compose.setContent
import androidx.activity.enableEdgeToEdge
import androidx.compose.foundation.layout.fillMaxSize
import androidx.compose.foundation.layout.padding
import androidx.compose.foundation.lazy.LazyColumn
import androidx.compose.foundation.lazy.items
import androidx.compose.material3.Scaffold
```

### Initialize Git Repository

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/chef

Set up version control for the Chef project by initializing a Git repository, staging all files, and creating an initial commit. The project includes a .gitignore file to exclude unnecessary files.

```bash
git init
git add --all
git commit -m "Initial commit"
```

### Reset Expo project directory

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/react-native

This command executes the `reset-project` script defined in the `package.json` file. It is used to clear the Expo project's cache and reset the `app` directory to a clean state, which can be useful during development.

```bash
npm run reset-project
```

--------------------------------

### Convex Record Type Example and Validation in JavaScript

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/database/types

Demonstrates a JavaScript object literal representing a Convex record, which allows for dynamic keys at runtime. The validation method is `v.record(keys, values)`. Keys must be ASCII, non-empty, and not start with '$' or '_'.

```javascript
{"a": "1", "b": "2"}
```

```javascript
v.record(keys, values)
```

--------------------------------

### Install Convex npm package

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/understanding/workflow

This command installs the Convex JavaScript SDK as a dependency in your project. It's a foundational step to integrate Convex into your application's build process and access its client-side utilities.

```bash
npm i convex
```

--------------------------------

### Build real-time todo list UI in SwiftUI

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/swift

Create a ContentView that displays a list of todos and subscribes to real-time updates from the Convex backend. The UI automatically refreshes whenever the backend data changes using async/await.

```swift
struct ContentView: View {
  @State private var todos: [Todo] = []

  var body: some View {
    List {
      ForEach(todos, id: \._id) { todo in
        Text(todo.text)
      }
    }.task {
      for await todos: [Todo] in convex.subscribe(to: "tasks:get")
        .replaceError(with: []).values
      {
        self.todos = todos
      }
    }.padding()
  }
}
```

--------------------------------

### Example Console Log Event JSON Schema

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/production/integrations/log-streams

This JSON example illustrates the structure of a `console` log event generated by the Convex platform. It includes fields such as `topic`, `timestamp`, `function` metadata, `log_level`, and the `message` content. This schema helps in parsing and processing log data for type-safe pipelines.

```json
{
    "topic": "console"
    "timestamp": 1715879172882,
    "function": {
      "path": "messages:send",
      "request_id": "d064ef901f7ec0b7",
      "type": "mutation"
    },
    "log_level": "LOG",
    "message": "'Sent message!'"
}
```

--------------------------------

### Example generated OpenAPI specification YAML

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/client/open-api

This snippet illustrates a partial example of the `convex-spec.yaml` file that is generated by the `npx convex-helpers open-api-spec` command. It defines the basic structure of the OpenAPI 3.0.3 specification, including API title, version, server URLs, and a general description of the Convex application's API. This YAML file serves as the input for client generation tools.

```yaml
# convex-spec.yaml
openapi: 3.0.3
info:
  title: Convex App - OpenAPI 3.0
  version: 0.0.0
  servers:
    - url: "{hostUrl}"
  description: Convex App API
  ...
```

--------------------------------

### GET /api/json_schemas

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/streaming-export-api

Lists all tables and provides JSON Schema descriptions for how documents will be encoded. Returns schema metadata including table references and field descriptions to guide data export implementations.

```APIDOC
## GET /api/json_schemas

### Description
Returns JSON Schema definitions for all tables in the Convex deployment, describing how documents are encoded and providing metadata about field relationships and special encodings.

### Method
GET

### Endpoint
/api/json_schemas

### Parameters
#### Query Parameters
- **deltaSchema** (boolean) - Optional - If set to true, include metadata fields returned by document_deltas and list_snapshot (_ts, _deleted, and _table)
- **format** (string) - Optional - Output format for values. Valid values: [json]

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
Returns JSON Schema object with $description tags throughout describing unintuitive encodings and table references.

#### Response Example
{
  "tables": [
    {
      "name": "tableName",
      "schema": {
        "type": "object",
        "properties": {
          "fieldName": {
            "type": "string",
            "$description": "Field description"
          }
        }
      }
    }
  ]
}
```

--------------------------------

### GET url

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/api/classes/browser.ConvexHttpClient

Retrieves the address for the current client instance. This URL is useful for creating a new client and may be canonicalized from the original construction address.

```APIDOC
## GET url

### Description
Return the address for this client, useful for creating a new client. Not guaranteed to match the address with which this client was constructed: it may be canonicalized.

### Method
GET

### Returns
- **url** (string) - The canonicalized address for this client

### Response Example
```
"https://your-deployment.convex.cloud"
```

### Defined in
browser/http_client.ts:147
```

--------------------------------

### Verify Node.js Version

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/tutorial

Command to check the installed Node.js version. Convex requires Node.js version 18 or greater for proper functionality and development.

```bash
node --version
```

--------------------------------

### Define sample data in JSON Lines format

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/quickstart/react-native

This code block represents a `sampleData.jsonl` file containing three lines of JSON objects. Each object defines a task with a `text` and `isCompleted` property, intended for populating a Convex database table.

```jsonl
{"text": "Buy groceries", "isCompleted": true}
{"text": "Go for a swim", "isCompleted": true}
{"text": "Integrate Convex", "isCompleted": false}
```

### Install Convex Component via npm

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/components/using

This command installs a Convex component package, such as `@convex-dev/agent`, as a dependency in your project. It adds the component's files to your `node_modules` directory, making its functionalities available for use in your Convex application.

```bash
npm i @convex-dev/agent
```

### Change Directory into App Folder

Source: https://docs.convex.dev/chef

Navigate to the application directory after extracting and renaming the downloaded Chef project folder. This command prepares the terminal environment for subsequent setup commands.

```bash
cd ~/<app folder>
```
